To access external devices (â€œScience Journal Sensorâ€) using Science Journal, you must first turn on Bluetooth. In order to discover Science Journal Sensors, Android requires you to also grant permission to access your location because other Bluetooth devices may broadcast their location information during device discovery. However, Science Journal will not store or use this location information, and Science Journal Sensors do not transmit location information.

The amount of light, measured in lux, reaching the ambient light sensor.
Jakost prostornog geomagnetskog polja u mikroteslama
Vanjski senzor ovdje prikazuje podatke na temelju prilagoÄ‘enih postavki.
Postotak izravnog neobraÄ‘enog oÄitanja s vanjskog senzora.
Atmosferski tlak mjeri se u hektopaskalima (hPa).

The ambient light sensor measures light in lux, a measure of illumination that depends on the amount of incoming light and the area over which it is spread.
A full moon provides about 1 lux of illumination, a typical lamp-lit living room about 50 lux, classroom lighting and sunrise and sunset about 400 lux, daylight (indirect sun) over 10,000 lux, and direct sun over 30,000 lux.
Lux is an unfamiliar unit for most of us. When we buy lightbulbs, we often shop by wattsâ€”but the wattage of a bulb doesn\'t tell you how bright a bulb is, only how much energy it uses. Lumens are a better measure for light shopping; they tell you how much light a bulb will actually produce. Lux, meanwhile, tells you how much of that light arrives at a particular area.

Since light spreads out as it travels, the number of lux dwindles as you back away from a light source, even though the source is still emitting the same amount of light in lumens. An area that is tilted away from a light sources also receives less illuminationâ€”which happens to be why the equatorial regions here on Earth are so much warmer than the chilly poles.
By the way, the purpose of the light sensor in your phone is to control the light level of the screen, adjusting accordingly to dim and bright environments. Inside the light sensor, a tiny semiconductor responds to incoming light by producing a small but measurable electrical currentâ€”a phenomenon known as the photoelectric effect. Similar sensors are used in some streetlights to turn them on when it gets dark outside.

VaÅ¡ telefon sadrÅ¾i ureÄ‘aj koji otkriva magnetska polja: magnetometar. Taj siÄ‡uÅ¡an senzor s tri osi pomoÄ‡u elektriÄne struje otkriva snagu magnetskog polja u tri prostorne dimenzije. Kombiniranjem podataka s tih triju osi moÅ¾emo izraditi senzor jaÄine cjelokupnog magnetskog polja.
Neki magnetometri otkrivaju magnetska polja pomoÄ‡u Hallova efekta â€“ sklonosti magnetskog polja da odbija naboj u pokretu. Noviji magnetometri imaju magnetske otpornike, metalne legure koje mijenjaju otpor s promjenom magnetskog polja.
ZaÅ¡to telefoni imaju magnetometar? Orijentacija u prostoru korisna je za aplikacije s ugraÄ‘enim kompasom i za navigaciju, prvenstveno one koje pokazuju detaljne navigacijske upute.

Magneti, elektriÄne struje i metalni predmeti mogu isto tako utjecati na magnetometar u telefonu. No Äak i usred praznog polja magnetometar u telefonu uvijek prikazuje nisku vrijednost koja nije nula: to je Zemljino magnetsko polje!

Tijela imaju tendenciju mirovanja, odnosno gibanja ako su u pokretu â€“ tu tendenciju nazivamo inercijom. Prvi Newtonov zakon tu ideju formalizira na sljedeÄ‡i naÄin: tijelo ostaje u stanju mirovanja ili gibanja sve dok neka sila ne dovede do promjene tog stanja.
Kad sila uzrokuje pomicanje tijela, kaÅ¾emo da ono ubrzava: njegova se brzina mijenja, bilo da se radilo o ubrzavanju, usporavanju ili promjeni smjera. Ubrzanje se mjeri kao promjena brzine u jedinici vremena (metri u sekundi), odnosno u metrima u sekundi na kvadrat (m/sÂ²).
VaÅ¡ telefon ima ureÄ‘aj koji mjeri te promjene kretanja â€“ akcelerometar. U akcelerometru se nalaze male mase koje se slobodno kreÄ‡u. Uslijed promjena u gibanju te se mase pomiÄu, sliÄno kao Å¡to se vaÅ¡a glava pomiÄe unaprijed ako se naÄ‘ete u automobilu koji naglo zakoÄi. MjereÄ‡i te suptilne inercijske pomake, akcelerometar u telefonu prepoznaje promjene u pokretima i smjeru, Å¡to je korisna znaÄajka prilikom okretanja zaslona iz pejzaÅ¾nog u portretni naÄin rada, igranja igara na telefonu i prilikom drugih radnji.

Vjerojatno ste primijetili neprekidno ubrzanje po osi Z, Äak i kad telefon leÅ¾i na stolu. To je ubrzanje kojem smo izloÅ¾eni zbog Zemljine gravitacije koja nas privlaÄi brzinom od pribliÅ¾no 9,8 m/sÂ².

Zvukove proizvode vibracije. Primjerice, vaÅ¡ glas nastaje vibriranjem vaÅ¡ih glasnica. Te vibracije stvaraju razliÄite zone visokog i niskog zraÄnog tlaka koje se Å¡ire prema van â€“ sliÄno kruÅ¾nom Å¡irenju valova koji nastaju kada u jezero bacite kamenÄiÄ‡.

Svi se zvukovi mogu opisati kroz svoju frekvenciju i intenzitet.
PomoÄ‡u senzora intenziteta zvuka u Science Journalu mjerite intenzitet u decibelima (dB). Intenzitet, odnosno glasnoÄ‡a, ovisi o udaljenosti koju tijelo koje vibrira prijeÄ‘e prilikom svake vibracije; veÄ‡i intenzitet doÅ¾ivljavamo kao veÄ‡u glasnoÄ‡u.
Frekvencija (ili visina tona) zvuÄnog vala ekvivalent je brzine vibracije. Å to brÅ¾e tijelo vibrira, to je nastali zvuk viÅ¡i. Senzor intenziteta zvuka u Science Journalu ne mjeri frekvenciju, veÄ‡ samo glasnoÄ‡u. Senzor intenziteta zvuka u Science Journalu ne mjeri frekvenciju, veÄ‡ samo glasnoÄ‡u.
VaÅ¾no je napomenuti da je mikrofon u vaÅ¡em ureÄ‘aju dizajniran tako da bude vrlo osjetljiv na razlike u zvuÄnim valovima tijekom vremena, ali ne i na apsolutnu veliÄinu svakog vala. PokuÅ¡ali smo odabrati kÃ´d koji Ä‡e vjerojatno generirati brojeve sliÄne referentnim brojevima koji su navedeni ispod, no svaki ureÄ‘aj moÅ¾e dati konzistentno veÄ‡e ili manje brojeve. Znanstvenici takve senzore obiÄno kalibriraju prema poznatim mjerenjima. Science Journal vam zasad moÅ¾e reÄ‡i je li vaÅ¡e sljedeÄ‡e putovanje vlakom glasnije od sljedeÄ‡eg rock koncerta, no samo ako ponesete telefon na ta mjesta.
JoÅ¡ jedna bitna napomena: postoje vaÅ¾ne razlike izmeÄ‘u \"intenziteta zvuka\", \"razine intenziteta zvuka\" i \"tlaka zvuka\". Ovdje ih tretiramo kao istu stvar, no ako Å¾elite produbiti svoja znanja, dostupni su brojni online resursi o njihovim razlikama.
NajtiÅ¡i zvuk koji prosjeÄno ljudsko uho moÅ¾e Äuti definira se kao 0 dB. UobiÄajeni razgovor odgovara vrijednosti od pribliÅ¾no 60 dB, a zvukovi iznad 140 dB bolni su za ljudsko uho. MeÄ‘utim, zvukovi ne moraju biti bolni da bi bili Å¡tetni. Neprekidna izloÅ¾enost zvukovima od 90 dB, Å¡to otprilike odgovara buci koju proizvodi usisavaÄ, moÅ¾e naposljetku dovesti do gubitka sluha.
Ljestvica decibela je logaritamska, zbog Äega izvor zvuka od 40 dB nije dvostruko intenzivniji od 20 dB, veÄ‡ 100 puta intenzivniji. Osim toga, ako jedna budilica daje 70 dB, dvije budilice ne daju 140 dB, veÄ‡ 73 dB. Kao Å¡to smo rekli, to je osebujna ljestvica.
10 dB: Å¡uÅ¡tanje liÅ¡Ä‡a 20 dB: Å¡apat na 1,5 m 30 dB: tihi Å¡apat 50 dB: kiÅ¡a 60 dB: normalan razgovor 90 dB: mikser 100 dB: automobil bez ispuÅ¡nog priguÅ¡ivaÄa 110 dB: vikanje u uho 120 dB: grmljavina 130 dB: pneumatska buÅ¡ilica 140: uzlijetanje zrakoplova

Zvukove proizvode vibracije. Primjerice, vaÅ¡ glas nastaje vibriranjem vaÅ¡ih glasnica. Te vibracije stvaraju razliÄite zone visokog i niskog zraÄnog tlaka koje se Å¡ire prema van â€“ sliÄno kruÅ¾nom Å¡irenju valova koji nastaju kada u jezero bacite kamenÄiÄ‡.

Svi se zvukovi mogu opisati kroz svoju frekvenciju i intenzitet. Frekvencija (ili visina tona) zvuÄnog vala ekvivalent je brzine vibracije. Å to brÅ¾e tijelo vibrira, to je nastali zvuk viÅ¡i. Te vibracije mjerimo u hercima (Hz), pri Äemu je 1 herc jednak 1 vibraciji u sekundi.
Ljudi mogu Äuti zvukove u rasponu od 20 do 20.000 Hz. Tipka za najdublji ton na klaviru stvara zvuk Äija frekvencija iznosi 27,5 Hz, a tipka za najviÅ¡i ton stvara zvuk frekvencije 4186,01 Hz.
Crvena toÄka oznaÄava koliko se prepoznata visina tona nalazi blizu najbliÅ¾e note. Ako je visina tona niÅ¾a (sniÅ¾en ton), toÄka se nalazi na lijevoj strani. Ako je visina tona viÅ¡a (poviÅ¡en ton), crvena toÄka nalazi se na desnoj strani.

Broj okretaja u minuti (o/min) mjera je frekvencije okretanja oko fiksne osi u jednoj minuti.
Kako se okreÄ‡e, vjetromjer okreÄ‡e disk kodera:
Tako nastaju razdoblja osvijetljenosti i zatamnjenja na senzoru, Å¡to Science Journal registrira kao okretaj.

Ovdje prikazani podaci rezultat su komunikacije vanjskog senzora s vaÅ¡im telefonom putem Bluetooth veze.
Vrijednost prikazuje postotak izravnog neobraÄ‘enog oÄitanja s mikrokontrolera. To je obiÄno vrijednost pada napona na senzoru.
Bluetooth je standard za beÅ¾iÄni prijenos podataka koji koristi radiovalove za razmjenu podataka izmeÄ‘u fiksnih i mobilnih ureÄ‘aja na malim udaljenostima.
Ovdje prikazani podaci rezultat su komunikacije vanjskog senzora s vaÅ¡im telefonom putem Bluetooth veze.
Bluetooth je standard za beÅ¾iÄni prijenos podataka koji koristi radiovalove za razmjenu podataka izmeÄ‘u fiksnih i mobilnih ureÄ‘aja na malim udaljenostima.

Iako to moÅ¾da tako ne doÅ¾ivljavamo, svi mi zapravo Å¾ivimo na dnu dubokog oceana zraka: Zemljine atmosfere visine od 40 km. Masa Äitavog tog zraka koji nas pritiÅ¡Ä‡e stvara atmosferski tlak.
Na morskoj razini atmosferski tlak iznosi 96 kPa, odnosno 96 njutna po kvadratnom metru. Za usporedbu, na podruÄju standardne veliÄine lista papira, ekvivalentna vrijednost tog pritiska iznosila bi pribliÅ¾no 8900 kPa.

Taj tlak ne osjeÄ‡amo jer smo na njega navikli, no primjeÄ‡ujemo Äak i njegove neznatne promjene, primjerice kad smo na veÄ‡im nadmorskim visinama ili u zrakoplovu. Atmosferski tlak ovisi i o vremenskim uvjetima: niÅ¾i je u podruÄju olujnog, nestabilnog zraka, a viÅ¡i kad je zrak stabilniji i nebo bez oblaka.
Digitalni barometar u telefonu mjeri atmosferski tlak u hektopaskalima. (Jedan hektopaskal iznosi 100 paskala, a paskal je jedan njutn sile po kvadratnom metru.) Vjerojatno ste Äuli da prognostiÄari iskazuju atmosferski tlak u milibarima. Ta jedinica moÅ¾da zvuÄi poznatije, ali istovjetna je hektopaskalu.
MoÅ¾da se pitate sljedeÄ‡e: zaÅ¡to se telefonom moÅ¾e mjeriti atmosferski tlak? Atmosferski tlak mijenja se Äak i uslijed sitnih promjena nadmorske visine, na primjer kad hodate uz stepenice. Dakle, digitalni barometar u vaÅ¡em telefonu moÅ¾e vam pomoÄ‡i u otkrivanju promjene lokacije. Primjerice, moÅ¾e vam reÄ‡i na kojem se katu zgrade nalazite ili vozite li se nadvoÅ¾njakom ili podvoÅ¾njakom.

The Arduino Science Journal is one of the BETT Award 2021 Finalist in the \"FREE DIGITAL CONTENT OR OPEN EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES\" category.
The Arduino Science Journal (formerly Science Journal, an initiative by Google) is free and open-source, and allows you to gather data about the world around you by harnessing the sensors in your smartphone as well as sensors connected to Arduino, or other third party hardware. The Science Journal transforms smartphones, tablets, and Chromebooks into science notebooks that encourage students to explore their world.
The Arduino Science Journal app is recommended for students from 10 to 18 years of age, and is available in 45 languages.
About the Science Journal
With the Arduino Science Journal, you can learn interactively, conduct experiments and iterate on findings.
â€¢ ğŸ’ª Enhance your existing lesson plans: use the Science Journal with activities and assignments you have already prepared â€¢ âœï¸ Classroom & home-school friendly: you donâ€™t have to be in a classroom setting to start exploring. The Arduino Science Journal can be used to run experiments straight away, as long as you have your smartphone or tablet with you! â€¢ ğŸŒ± Move learning outside: the use of mobile devices along with the types of experiments we offer encourage students to get out of their seats and open their eyes to the world around them through the power of science â€¢ ğŸ” Science and data have no secrets: you can easily record your observations, store your data sensors in real-time and analyse them, just as a proper scientist! â€¢ ğŸ”„ Connect the digital and the physical world from your pocket: go through a series of simple tutorials and start having fun with science
It transforms different devices such as smartphones, tablets, and Chromebooks, into a pocket-size science tool that encourages you to explore your world. As students conduct experiments, theyâ€™ll record observations and make new, exciting discoveries. Through documentation and reflections, students can conduct experiments just like any other scientist. You can use the app as it is, using the sensors included in your smartphone or tablet, or use external hardware like sensors and microcontrollers that are compatible with bluetooth connections, to run more demanding experiments. By using external sensors, the students can extend their experimentation and learning. For a more in-depth experience of the world of science, the app comes with different topic-related lessons - available for students and teachers alike!
The app is classroom-friendly, since students can sign in on any device and access their experiments to continue exploring the world, wherever they are!
Permissions notice: â€¢ ğŸ“Location: Needed to scan for Bluetooth sensor devices. â€¢ ğŸ“· Camera: Needed to take pictures to document experiments. â€¢ ğŸ™Microphone: Needed for sound intensity sensor. â€¢ ğŸ“¥Storage: Needed to access photos to insert into experiments.
Benefits of using the Arduino Science Journal â€¢ Itâ€™s free and simple to use â€¢ Easy setup: download the app and start exploring with your phoneâ€™s built-in sensors â€¢ Cross-platform: supports Android, iOS, and Chromebooks â€¢ Portable: enhance your home learning or bring your device outside to study the world around you â€¢ Safe for children to use: COPPA Compliance underway â€¢ Fully compatible with Arduino hardware: keep experimenting with the Arduino Science Kit Physics Lab, as well as the Arduino Nano 33 BLE Sense board â€¢ Compatible with third-party hardware â€¢ Fully open-source: you can develop your own hardware support as the app is open-source â€¢ Google Drive integration (coming soon), as well as local download

Orijentacija telefona u odnosu na Zemljino magnetsko polje.

Vjerojatno veÄ‡ znate da Zemlja ima magnetsko polje. No moÅ¾da ne znate da vaÅ¡ telefon sadrÅ¾i ureÄ‘aj koji otkriva magnetska polja: magnetometar. Ako podatke s magnetometra telefona poveÅ¾emo s orijentacijom telefona u prostoru, moÅ¾emo izraditi digitalni kompas.
ObiÄan kompas vrsta je magnetometra \"stare tehnologije\", Äija se igla pomiÄe uslijed djelovanja magnetskog polja. Telefoni u sebi nemaju siÄ‡uÅ¡an kompas, veÄ‡ senzor s tri osi koji pomoÄ‡u elektriÄne struje otkriva snagu magnetskog polja u tri prostorne dimenzije. No to nije dovoljno za izradu kompasa!
ZaÅ¡to je za kompas potrebno povezati podatke s magnetometra i orijentaciju telefona? Orijentacija telefona omoguÄ‡uje nam da izraÄunamo magnetsku rotaciju Äak i kad telefon nije postavljen ravno, u istoj ravnini kao Zemljino magnetsko polje. BuduÄ‡i da znamo da gravitacija djeluje okomito na Zemljino magnetsko polje, moÅ¾emo upotrijebiti smjer gravitacije iz senzora akcelerometra da bismo utvrdili koliko je magnetskog polja u istoj ravnini kao Zemljino magnetsko polje.

MoÅ¾da ste primijetili da kompas ne reagira samo na Zemljino magnetsko polje, veÄ‡ i na svako drugo magnetsko polje u njegovoj blizini. Magneti, elektriÄne struje i metalni predmeti mogu isto tako utjecati na magnetometar u telefonu i uzrokovati promjene u oÄitavanju kompasa. IziÄ‘ite na otvoreni prostor, po moguÄ‡nosti van i podalje od elektriÄnih vodova, da biste bili sigurni da se crveni vrÅ¡ak magnetometra poravnao sa Zemljinim magnetskim poljem. Ako trebate kalibrirati magnetometar u telefonu, izvodite telefonom kretnje u obliku brojke 8.
Ukupno ubrzanje telefona u m/sÂ², iskljuÄujuÄ‡i silu gravitacije

Tijela imaju tendenciju mirovanja, odnosno gibanja ako su u pokretu â€“ tu tendenciju nazivamo inercijom. Prvi Newtonov zakon tu ideju formalizira na sljedeÄ‡i naÄin: svako tijelo ostaje u stanju mirovanja ili gibanja sve dok neka sila ne dovede do promjene tog stanja.
Kad sila uzrokuje pomicanje tijela, kaÅ¾emo da ono ubrzava: njegova se brzina mijenja, bilo da se radilo o ubrzavanju, usporavanju ili promjeni smjera. Ubrzanje se mjeri kao promjena brzine u jedinici vremena (metri u sekundi), odnosno u metrima u sekundi na kvadrat (m/sÂ²).
VaÅ¡ telefon ima ureÄ‘aj koji mjeri te promjene kretanja â€“ akcelerometar. U akcelerometru se nalaze male mase koje se slobodno kreÄ‡u. Uslijed promjena u gibanju te se mase pomiÄu, sliÄno kao Å¡to se vaÅ¡a glava pomiÄe unaprijed ako se naÄ‘ete u automobilu koji naglo zakoÄi. MjereÄ‡i te suptilne inercijske pomake, akcelerometar u telefonu prepoznaje promjene u pokretima i smjeru, Å¡to je korisna znaÄajka prilikom okretanja zaslona iz pejzaÅ¾nog u portretni naÄin rada, igranja igara na telefonu i prilikom drugih radnji.
Senzor kombiniranog linearnog akcelerometra biljeÅ¾i ukupno ubrzanje za sve tri osi telefona, osim gravitacije.
PokuÅ¡ajte sastaviti biljeÅ¡ke i biljeÅ¾iti podatke putem alatne trake u nastavku!

Experiment data for Science Journal is saved and made available across devices using Google Drive and requires signing in with a Google account.
If you have existing data on this device, once signed in, you can save your existing experiments to Google Drive. Your experiments are stored in a \u201CScience Journal\u201D folder in Google Drive.
Na taj su raÄun primijenjene postojeÄ‡e postavke ureÄ‘aja

resources.string: Jeste li sigurni da Å¾elite ukloniti naslovnu sliku? Tu radnju ne moÅ¾ete poniÅ¡titi.

Using augmented reality, track and measure objects
The amount of flow of charged particles between two places
A device that measures orientation and angular velocity (rotation).
An instrument used to measure the intensity and direction of a magnetic field
The measure of the difficulty of current flow through an object or material
The difference in electric potential between two places that allows a current to flow
Ambient temperature in C or F
A barometric sensor is used to measure air pressure in a certain environment. Air Pressure can impact short term changes in the weather. The Barometric Air Pressure is measured in Atmosphere or atm.
A humidity sensor is an electronic device that measures the humidity in its environment and converts it into an electrical signal. Relative humidity is measured in %.
The ambient light sensor measures light in lux, a measure of illumination that depends on the amount of incoming light and the area over which it is spread. The amount of light is measured in lux.

Color temperature is a characteristic of visible light that has important applications in many industries, such as: lighting, photography, astrophysics, manufacturing, and other fields. Color temperature is expressed in Kelvins (K), a unit of measurement for absolute temperature.
The CIE 1931 x,y chromaticity space, also showing the chromaticities of black-body light sources of various temperatures (Planckian locus), and lines of constant correlated color temperature.

A proximity sensor is a sensor able to detect the presence of nearby objects without any physical contact. A proximity sensor often emits an electromagnetic field or a beam of electromagnetic radiation (infrared, for instance), and looks for changes in the field or return signal. The object being sensed is often referred to as the proximity sensor\'s target. Proximity here is measured in millimeters or mm.
Weâ€™re done checking for permissions. If you need to modify these permissions in the future, you can do so at any time in the Science Journal app settings of the Android Settings app.
Start taking notes and record data using the observation toolbar.
Find activities and inspiration at science-journal.arduino.cc and start exploring the world around you.
If you missed the Getting Started guide or you want to go back to it, you can find it in the sidebar menu.
This introduction will walk you through the most important functions of Science Journal and show you how to turn your smart device into a pocket science lab. Swipe left to begin.
You can always get back to this intro later in the sidebar menu.
Science Journal helps you to conduct science experiments by allowing you to observe real time sensor data, record sensor values as well as add notes and observations to your experiments.
Did you know that smartphones come with various built-in sensors? Connect an Arduino board to add even more advanced sensors.
Add a new experiment to start exploring & journaling
An experiment lets you organise all your observations and recordings of a specific topic. Create a new experiment, give it a suitable name and start exploring the sensors.
Add a picture from your gallery
Document different types of observations through the observation toolbar. You can add a text note or photo to your experiment or create a sensor recording.
Pick a built-in phone sensor or connect an Arduino board to see live sensor data.
You can add multiple sensors to your experiment to observe them simultaneously.
To capture sensor data and save it to your experiment you can either start a recording or you can use the snapshot function.
Start a recording to capture the change of sensor values over time.
Create a point-in-time snapshot to capture the current sensor values.
It can be challenging to look at the display while doing an experiment. Tap â€œEnable audioâ€ to transform sensor values into audible sound.

All your experiments can now be saved and accessed from anywhere with the Cloud Sync feature. By tapping on the \"Google Drive\" button you are agreeing to Googleâ€™s permission and privacy policy to enable the backup, and sync of your experiments in a Google Drive folder of your choice, in accordance with Google T&Cs and privacy policy. You will be redirected to Googleâ€™s authentication page to complete your Cloud Sync.

The Arduino Science Journal app and Arduino never access your experiments created in the App, as they are only saved locally, nor do they access your documents in Google Drive, under any circumstances, even when Cloud Sync is active. The Arduino Science Journal app will ask for your permission to see, create and delete files with the sole purpose of saving and backing up your experiments in a Google Driveâ€™s folder of your choice. You can change your preferences at any time straight from your Google account, or you can decide to revoke Cloud Syncâ€™s access directly from the App. If you use a Google Account through your organization or school, you may not be able to back up your files. Check with your administrator first. If you have any doubt about Google Drive policies and/or if you have any problems related to the updates of Google Drive, please contact directly Google, as only the latter can help you deal with problems on your Google Drive account and folders. If you have any doubts or questions about Google\'s policies, permissions and privacy policies, please read Googleâ€™s T&Cs and privacy policy.
Choose where you would like to save your experiments
Your experiments will be automatically synced in the folder â€œ%sâ€ on your Drive.

Check your email, we just sent you a link to complete the reset of your password.

We sent you an email to finalize your registration. In order to continue, please follow the instructions and activate your account. Once your account is activated, you can login to Science Journal.
Sign in with a Junior account
This extra step shows that itâ€™s really you trying to sign in. Get a verification code from the Authenticator app.
The username is the word you used to sign in to your account. If you do not remember your username, ask your parent to restore your account from their Arduino profile page.
Ask your parent to check their email inbox to reset your accountâ€™s password.
A parent needs to help you create the account. Enter their email address below and we will send instructions on how to proceed.
You may use the following actions to collect, export or discard those experiments:
Delete an experiment from the device
Experiment data for Science Journal can be saved and made available across devices using Google Drive which requires signing in with a Google Account.
If you have existing data on this device, once signed in, you can save your existing experiments to Google Drive. Your experiments are stored in a folder of your choice in Google Drive.

The username is created for you automatically, but you can generate new ones until you find the best one. You will use this username to log in to Arduino, and other users will see it when you post projects.
